Since I've heard of coworkers getting sick off their sushi, and since my food was pretty meh, I don't think I'll be back.  Sorry, tricky Chinese people, but you can't win me over this time.

I forgot to mention that this place gets 2 stars because they have a credit card machine.
author: Tori S.

description: The formula is very easy: 1) you can take the food from the floating boats, and then you pay for what you eat according to the colour of the plate (from 0.99$ to 4.99$ a plate), and 2) you can order directly to them after have seen the menu! The basic rolls start from 6$ and the special ones cost about 14$. A plate of yaki soba costs about $10
author: Marica C.

description: I like to stop for lunch when visiting but it is expensive for average sushi and a wait staff that orders you around, "sit there," "more beer."
author: Lenny S.

description: so i should have checked yelp first. we stayed away from the floating sushi it didn't look very fresh.(3pm) we had the ramen noodles. for 11.00 is was just ok.  2 pieces of pork belly & 1/2 egg. you can get excellent ramen for under 11.00 at ramen dojo in san mateo. the worst part of this was they put 10% tip on the bill automatically. i complained and they said they alway do it. i had alrady left a cash tip on the counter. i asked where they have it posted. of course they didn't.  they refunded my card and recharge with out tip. i will be calling my credit card company tomorrow. i left gave back my cash tip to the water after but it was less then 10% because the service was pathetic.
author: Cheryl B.

description:
Ive been here a couple times in the last several years and today reminded me why I didnt want to go back.
Dirty, rude, and disgusting!
Sushi boats have mildew growing on the sides. Sushi on the boats were cold and the rice was crunchy. I took a shrimp dumpling from the boat and as I brought it to my plate, the waitress grabbed it from my hand and said "I heat up! I heat up" without a choice. It returned at 195 degrees- burned the crap out of my mouth and it was dried out.

I PROMISE TO NEVER GO HERE EVER AGAIN-

DEAR TOURISTS- RUN!!!! RUN FAR!!! Sincerely, A SF local.
author: Mario M.

description:
The waitress was mean, helping to decide our order so I was in a foul mood. (The day of the chinese new years fair) It was pretty empty. The breaded pork was room temperature and dry, the rice was ok. I also didnt like how I didn't know what was in the salad dressing but I assume it's the Japanese style dressing: mayonaisse with some type of dried fish? Or something lol. The edamame was nice and warm though. I was sitting by the window so if you want wasabi, ask the waitress. The soy sauce is on the table. They speak Chinese and enough English.

Definitely not coming here again because the cost and what I got didn't match up. =/ I really wanted to like it too!
author: Victoria H.

description:
On August 10 at 4:00 PM, I took my mother to Floating Sushi for a lunch date. Let me start off by saying that the workers here are all RUDE. I didn't even bother to tip them, it was really that bad. Let me elaborate.

My mother and I decided to come in here as the front windows advertised $.99 cent plates, after coming in, we found out those plates are just jello and cookies. But they have bento boxes so this place was starting to look up. I ordered salmon teriyaki with tempura. When I received my food, it all tasted old. My salmon, was burned and so was my mother's. We ordered tapioca drinks and you can just tell the tapioca was old. Like, from the day before. The drinks, were still powered on the bottom and when brought to the attention of the workers they give you attitude and don't even offer to make you another one. While I was eating, I nearly threw up as one of the workers decided to clean the drains for the "floating boat sushi area" right next to me. She literally pulled the drain plug out and left the debris catcher next to my bento box as she went to grab tupper ware to put it in. When she came back, she dumped the contents into the container and put it right back in. That isn't even the grossest part. She then took the order that was waiting from the top of the sushi bar to hand another customer her food. For this, I will never come back.Upon asking for my check, the lady working wouldn't hand me my receipt. Now this sounds a little strange but let me point out that she brought everyone else their bills and as for myself, she told me from across the restaurant to come to her for it. This puzzled me, including the people who sat next to me -who was handed their check.So if you happen to work here and was present that day, the little girl that didn't tip anything. THIS REVIEW EXPLAINS EXACTLY WHY.
author: Shilo B.

description: The staff was really nice but disorganized; three different people approached us about drinks until our water finally came. Most of the rolls on the boat were basically avocado and imitation crab (yes, it's imitation because I'm allergic to real crab), decorated with roe or eel on top or fried. We were rather disappointed at the "choice" thus ordered a caterpillar roll off the menu. Overall I found everything soft and decadent which was perfect since my jaw gets tired easily. I peeked at the chef as he piled on the rice and smushed it onto the seaweed (making the roll denser and the customer fuller on cheap grains) and some of the rolls were actually falling apart when picked it up because they weren't rolled tightly! It was $25 for those 12 pieces of sushi..this place is for tourists, not for foodies. Two stars because the staff are trying, but I wouldn't recommend this place
author: Betty Z.

description:
Walked with no expectations at all as I believe it's a tourist trap. I'm in Chinatown, San Francisco, go figure :P 

When ordering, the waitress quickly suggested their Fresh Watermelon Juice. I ordered a chicken terayaki plate that came with miso soup and white rice. I thought the Fresh Watermelon juice was a bit warm and would have been nice if it was COLD but instead it was  warm :(

Terayaki dish wasn't good as the meat was burnt and I could taste the charcoal :( Not recommending place at all.
author: Brian L.

description: This is a great little spot if you just want to stop and have a quick bit to eat and not be harassed by wait staff... we sat at the sushi bar. It was fun to be able to pick what we wanted to eat as it floated passed us. There are a number of choices so you can defiantly find something you will like.
author: Misty L.

description:
So a friend and I decided to venture out to Chinatown this past Sunday. It was absolutely gorgeous and sunny which is out of the norm for this time of year. So I thought what better way to spend the day than being in the city. Sadly my excitement came to a halt after my dining experience at The Floating Sushi Boat. The not-so-friendly staff, and empty seats should have been a hint of what was yet to come but we decided to stay anyway. 

I ordered the "Super Duper Roll" and also picked up something that resembled Unagi off of the floating boat. The sushi was poorly assembled and not very fresh. I was clearly mistaken by the Unagi by the way, which tasted like a cheap imitation and was very cold. I am by no means a picky eater but the food was just terrible. The waitress never checked on us once which I found very unsatisfactory as we were the only ones dining at the moment. 

I was shocked when I got the bill, not only was it outrageously overpriced they had also included an 18% gratuity. When we questioned it the hostess replied "yeah you tip because we make the food and clean the plates". Call me crazy but I was under the impression that when you go to a restaurant they cook for you. I will not be dining here again.
author: Lauren D.

description: I love this place! I'm from Long Beach, about 6 hours away, but every time I come to SF, I make sure I go here. The staff is very nice and the food is good. You can spend as little as you want, and still have a nice amount of food as well as a great experience.
author: Heather R.

description: Where do I start. My girlfriend and I stopped here to try out their sushi. It looked interesting from the outside, but when we walked in it looked messy and disorganized. Their selection on the floating boat sushi wasn't great either. Taste wise, not worth the price. Service was horrible. They also tried to charge us for our drinks that we brought in even though they were clear starbucks cups. The worst part was that when they rung us up the lady automatically wrote a tip in for herself and just asked us to sign. Go somewhere else. Horrible experience, if I could give 0 stars I would.
author: Samuel H.

description: 1st off, avoid the bento boxes for this place is primarily for sushi. 2nd, most bad reviews were looking for the cheap stuff. you really don't want to eat cheap sushi-you know what I mean? I always keep an open mind and know that the signs posted are teasers to get you in, like used car lots. Sushi in Chinatown? You betcha. My expectation low for many eateries in Chinatown are mediocre at best. this place would be a hit if it was closer to the financial district lunch crowd. the ika and tako was the freshest I have ever tasted. not like other places where the stuff sits there in room temp. sushi chef will make you anything you request.  ashamed to say that after moving away from SF, I discovered a place I would have frequented if I was a local.
author: Luis G.

description:
if there was a zero star, that's what I'd pick. This place is beyond horrible. I was craving sushi and around the area and saw the 99 cent sushi sign plastered everywhere on their windows and cool sushi boat style.

I went in and anything that was 99 cent was JELLO on a sushi dish? are you friggen kidding me??? that aint  mother BEEPIN sushi! despite the trickery, i stayed and waited for the boats to go around at least 3 times and it was the same 3-4 sushi kinds over and over, i tried them, i can make better sushi than that, and i am not a cooker! i was sooo pissed. so after like 3 dishes i asked for my check...i looked closely and they added the tip already. wtf is that, i choose to tip you or not unless im over a party of 6 or more. ugh i had a $18 meal of UNSATISFACTORY! 

BEWARE, COME AT YOUR OWN RISK!
author: Tam T.

description:
Possibly one of the worst restuarants I ever been to.

 PLEASE AVOID AT ALL COST!!!!. 

If i could give this place negative stars, i would give it (-100) + infinity..
author: Jenny L.

description: My worse sushi experience. I went in without going online and from the reception, cleanliness, and the quality of food was a disaster, from now on I'll check yelp or Google before spending my hard earned cash
author: Wal B.

description: I stopped eating as soon as I saw the little black flies buzzing around the boats like seagulls at the dock.
author: Ann E.

description: Disgusting.  PERIOD.. If zero star was available, that's what I would give them. Place is nasty looking and dirty as hell
author: John Rommel A.

description: This was a bad experience for many reasons. One, the woman working came across as rude and abrupt. Some of it can be attributed to cultural difference, but mostly she was just unfriendly and had seemed to lack customer service skills. The sushi chef, meanwhile, was talking on her cell phone which was right next to our table. The food was overpriced, based on other experiences I've had in the area. For example, we ordered pork spring rolls (3) and they were quite small (seriously, like the size of baby carrots) and it cost $6. In terms of quality, the sushi looked very unfresh and they were  definitely not cold nor refrigerated. All-in-all, this came across as a big tourist trap that I would not recommend.
author: Kevin A.

description:
Hell no. (Haelllll-nahhh)

Rudest staff I've ever encountered in my life. I'm not sure the waitress even looked up at us. 

The lighting in this place was awful. It looked dirty. Smelled like a combination of stagnant water & fish heads. 

Avoid.
author: Robby S.

description:
It's very bad place slow service, bad maner.

The manager and worker was arguing inside really loud. So the manager has a wrong order for us and when we ask her she tread us very bad. Later, the cook saw our order and show us and her, without any sorry or anything make the customer feel better and comfortable with the restaurant. I wish I was know that on Yelp at the first side.

The food is expensive. Don't be fool by the advertise that sad sushi 99 cents and up! what you could get for the 99 cents is 3 pieces of watermelon. Good Luck!!!
author: Tung V.

description:
After our food was delivered, the staff never came by our table again. We got the waitress's attention after just sitting there for a while to ask for the bill. She said "okay" and walked off. 

We waited for at least 20 minutes but she never came back with the bill so we decided to go up to the counter and wait. The waitress walked by and we asked to pay. She replied "in a minute" as she walked away yet again. We then waited at the counter for another 5-10 minutes before she comes back and finally lets us pay... 

The worst part? They automatically added a 15% gratuity for our party of four...
author: Sera G.

description:
I love my kaiten, and the .99 special on the sign outside made me think quick and cheap snack.
The angry looking chef who hovered over me was reason enough to leave. The .99 special was nasty looking jello. 
After almost deciphering the prices (REALLY intricate plates indicate the prices), I decided nothing looked appetizing. Left $2 for their trouble and left.
author: T P.

description: The servers at this restaurant took an incredibly long time to attend to anyone. The food is overpriced, and our order was misunderstood three times -- and they still charged us. Do NOT recommend.
author: John S.

description: This place was nothing special. The food was very lacking in flavor (we got honey lemon chicken and beef chow fun with a side of pot stickers) I wish we would have looked this place up on yelp before ordering! The portions were okay, but I expected more for the price: $30+ The only thing good I can say is the pot stickers were pretty good. Don't waste your time, or money!
author: Richard C.

description:
My friend thought it would be a good idea to eat here. Who wouldn't when you are staring through the window late at night in China town after the place closed. Who doesn't want to eat sushi that floats around a c crappy moat in cool looking boats. He couldn't have been more wrong. 

I was the first to sit down and the hostess seemed nice enough. She explained the sushi was priced on the plate it came on. She also showed me their most popular Jello dish which I saw over and over and over again. It was orange jello.  "Just stop the boats and take what you want!" Seemed easy enough to me.

Soon everyone showed up and after further inspection of the sushi floating around we all agreed that if it sucked we would just leave and go somewhere better. I am not a picky eater and started hammering down sushi. It probably wasn't until my fifth or sixth piece that I noticed the rice was crunchy.  Not very good. Everyone else had figured this out well before me and I am sure were asking themselves what the hell was wrong with me and why did I keep putting this garbage in my mouth.

Sadly the friend that picked this restaurant had to deal with a sick wife as a result of what was floating around endlessly in those boats. She looked sick after dinner....like an old cat. Just don't go. It sucks. The only fun I had was playing games with the people a couple of seats down by stopping the boats directly in front of me so they had to wait until the sushi they wanted floated over to them .
author: John O.

description: don't do it. just don't. filthy. undercooked rice.. (at a sushi restaurant) and WORST OF ALL! the waitresses! ABSOLUTELY the RUDEST people I've encountered in my 40something years! don't spend your money here.
author: S K.

description:
This was a funny dining experience with a group. The server ignored us so we laughed at how long it took for us to get someones attention. The food was OK and the service was horrible but we were happy to the enjoy the City experience. 

I won't come back but it was a memorable experience.
author: Sweet S.

description:
Avoid this place. I was also lured in by the .99 Cent Sushi Special. 

The sushi boat selection was weak, mostly California Rolls, Egg, Cooked Prawns - what I'd like to call Tourist Sushi. None of those items were 99 cents either, the only items that were 99 cents were jello, 3  cookies that obviously came from a package and 3 slices of watermelon. Seriously. 

The worse part of the lunch was when I picked up one of the rolls and found a tiny black hair under it. I wanted to throw up right there. I gave it back to the waitress and she acted like it wasn't a big deal and asked me if I wanted something else. - EEK! Me thinks not, not ever.
author: Rebekah T.

description: I wish there were negative stars. Worst sushi of my life. Day old grocery store sushi is a million times better. Prices are not as good as advertised out front. The people who work there are some of the nastiest I've ever met. They just don't care. It's a tourist trap. Wish we'd checked yelp before going in. Don't let the kitschy floating boats fool you. If you want a miserable experience, look no further! With sooo many good food options nearby, run as fast as you can away from this place.
author: Gabrielle F.

description: Overall its not terrible, but by San Francisco standards its lacking. The Chicken Ramen had all the fat left on the meat. some people may like that but not me. However the broth was excellent. the Sushi was lacking and the service was minimal. to sum it up in one word; Meh.
author: Jason T.

description:
The only way this place could have been worse is if we had gotten sick. I'm glad that didn't happen.

Okay, let me start out by saying that I know better than to eat Japanese food not only in a touristy part of San Francisco, by in Chinatown of all places, where there's enough amazing dim sum to satisfy even a Texas-sized hunger. Unfortunately, we were between walking tours and had only 20 minutes to eat lunch - so a sushi boat seemed ideal. Well, time-wise it nearly was, but I think that's the only possible positive I can come up with.

The one lady making sushi was dead to the world - no interaction with any of the folks at the bar at all - and very lackluster with the selection of sushi she was putting together. In fact, she really only did one roll - California roll. There was some attempt to mask it by putting different things on top, but there was no fooling anyone. Especially when everything was thick and sloppily mashed together and fell apart the moment it was touched with chopsticks. Well, at least the ingredients were fresh, right? Yeah no - the avocado was already brown when it made it's first (though likely just the start of endless) loops around the moat. The fish itself was paper thin, too, so no salvation to be found even there. Oh, best part was the ridiculous price!

It's hard to explain further why this place wasn't good. It just... wasn't good. At all. The servers seemed dazed and unhappy, the atmosphere was oppressive, and it took us forever to get our check despite being the only people paying at the time. So if you see this in time, or any of the many other negative reviews - take heed and avoid this pit of terrible sushi!
author: Marie S.

description: This place doesn't deserve a star in any category whatsoever. My boyfriend and I stopped here because r&g was packed and we wanted sushi, not being from sf we had no idea what mistake that was. I ordered the beef & chicken teriyaki, which came out cold and the beef was all fat! Not only was that 16$...ridiculous for teriyaki, but the 'waitress' never got us water or wanted to reheat my food. Then when it came time to pay, SHE AUTOMATICALLY ADDED GRADITUITY. Are you joking? Infuriated to say the least. This place is a health hazard and needs to be shut down.
author: Alanna L.

description: This place is crap. The staff is rude. The food is crapy. I ordered one sushi pIate of 12 pieces and fried banana and it turned out to be $19! Plus I had terrible stomach pain a couple of hours after I ate their sushi. I should have known better as there was only one person when I came in. The place itself is not the most neat and clean. Never coming here again.
author: Aleksandra S.

description: Frankly, I don't get the unfavorable reviews. Food & service are quite good. And I love the watermelon juice.
author: Hans M.

description:
Over priced and low quality sushi.  Terrible place to eat.  Skip it and you will be happier.

Most of the dishes that you will eat are either $3 or $4 for two pieces of nigiri.   They are at premium price that you can get at other places, yet the quality of the food is low.

The restaurant is also dirty and the server charged us 15% for group of 6 sitting at sushi bar.    We walked out of door about $120 for 6.  You can have better food at that price easily.
author: George H.

description: This is a really cool concept but the sushi is mediocre. Good for just basic sushi. Is very clean and has fast service, but nothing special. More like fast food sushi.
author: Reisha B.

description: Why would you eat sushi in Chinatown? My family and I came here once when they have some special, but otherwise it is way overpriced. Go to Japantown!
author: Jennifer T.

description:
This review will be very short as my visit here was quite short. 

After having an awesome haircut by Kimberly G. at Jackson Place Salon, I was traipsing around Chinatown looking for something simple and maybe falling in the category of hole in the wall. I remembered sitting down with a group of tourists 8 years ago during my first visit to S.F. and marveling at the little sushi boats and fun little selections.

That was 8 years ago.

Skip to a Thursday afternoon and take one look at what they've got on stock now and it's basically dried up rolls that are so rock hard the rice is almost turning clear and brown. Unacceptable indeed. I paid for the edamame and tea and looked for my first sign of sustenance in the form of shrimp with black bean sauce. What was I thinking trying to get sushi in Chinatown? Of course it's sacrilege!
author: Jessica K.

description: The service was awful and the food was not good as well. We only got Ramen and it didn't even have any flavor at all. Absolutely cannot recommend that place.
author: Katharina E.

description: Good casual Sushi. Non intrusive staff. Authentic ambiance. Clean, open space. Conveniently located
author: Healthy F.

description: nice place, good food, but not enough to put 5 stars. it s close to china town and it s very tipical of this aerea. the plates are in the boats that sail into a channel around the chef. amazing!
author: Giovanni S.

description: We went here for lunch and ordered curry beef, chicken teriyaki lunch box and yakisoba. Horrible service. The lady gave us wrong items. We had to ask for cutlery because she didn't seem able to count how many people were at our table (only 3). The glasses and plates were unwashed (we had to exchange them TWICE). Honestly we wanted to leave but decided to stay because we had already placed the order. The food was very disappointing too. 1 star only because there is no option for a zero star.
author: Tanvi P.

description: OMG I WISH I HAD READ YELP BEFORE GOING HERE. The service was terrible and the food even worse. Was in the mood for sushi and thought--hey--why not! I had walked into one of the Chinese restaurants nearby and walked back out bc nothing appealed to me, and I had already seen this place and thought--sushi!  I got the combo A, bc i thought that would be fresher sushi then was going around on the boats since they would have had to make it, but i'm pretty sure they just took it off of the boats. It was way worse than supermarket sushi, which is like the bottom of the barrel for me. So gross. Don't waste your money.
author: Ginny N.

description: The server was very rude, had no patience, would disappear for a long time and never came back to check if I wanted anything else. On top of it, the food was bad.
author: Jigesha D.

description: Loved what I had...BUT THE SERVICE IS AWFUL!!!  They acted like they didn't want us in the place.  Prepare to get what  is only in the boats.  They are not in the mood to help you.  Stay away from the udon...in fact, just don't go.
author: Chris K.

description:
Was curious about this place. Glad I checked it out because I am curious no longer. Boring meal. Boring interior. Old looking sushi. Messy presentation. Bye bye $10. 

Skip this place.
author: Rich_kids_of_yelp Z.

description: HORRIBLE customer service. If there zero stars I'd give that.
author: Alex R.

description: I generally like the train/boat concept especially when I'm hungry and want something quick. And for that convenience I lower my expectations. This place didn't come close to meeting those lowered expectations. The staff was polite enough and attentive contrary to other reviews I read. However, the food was terrible. The salmon nigiri from the boat resembled the consistency of smoked salmon. I ordered a roll with tuna which wasn't any better and abandoned that to wait on my chicken "yakatori" figuring that would be hard to mess up. What arrived appeared to have been fried rather than grilled, was full of fat, and smothered in a sweet teriyaki sauce. I spit out the one bite I took and got up to pay my bill, leaving almost all of my food on the sushi bar. $35 later I walked out without one question about how the food was or why it remained uneaten.
author: Jason S.

description: I'm sorry was somebody looking for sushi in china town . What the fuck was I thinking . Im offended that a place like this even exists. I gave them a chance the sushi in the boats were old and dried out looked like jerky . So I ordered from the menu a tempura roll which was pre made from earlier I would guess. Rolled and cut in the skinniest slices you cheap bastards. I'm Japanese you offended my taste buds and the rice you wasted to make sushi!!!!!!!!
author: William W.

description:
WOW, after reading these reviews, it really makes me not want to go even more. I was down here in SF for a vacation. For the first day, I actually ate at a restaurant down the street after seeing this place. I'm a sushi fiend and sushi is what I love to eat. I wanted to eat here because I never experienced a floating sushi boat restaurant before. This is just a different type of experience to eat sushi and I wanted to go even more--past tense, "wanted." 

So I walked inside just to see what time they closed. It was already 11pm, so I was thinking it closes late. I walked in and asked the lady, which you can already tell she couldn't speak fluent English, "What time do you close?" Surprisingly, she had no answer!! What kind of a restaurant doesn't know when the establishment closes. I was shocked but at the same time laughing inside. 

So the next day, I was in the same area again, and I thought to myself, "Self, let's go back and order a spicy scallop hand roll." When I asked the waitress to order, she said that there's "NO MORE." That's when I knew never to come back. Even something as small as scallops, they don't keep extra in stock. That is ridiculous. 

I didn't even try the food, just from that experience and I knew never to go back into that place ever again!!!
author: Joanna H.

description:
GROSS.  I should have Yelped the place before we walked in, or at least seen it as a bad sign that there were a lot of people out that day and this place was totally empty.  The sushi was probably floating in a circle for at least an hour before we got there.  The rice was crunchy, the fish was warm, and the service wasn't much better.  To top it all off, the toilet paper holder even fell apart when I stopped in the bathroom before we left.

Interestingly enough, once we left we ran into a bartender from the last place we stopped and told him about our terrible experience, and he basically said "that's what you get for sushi in Chinatown."  FAIL!
author: Megan K.

description:
Floating Sushi Boat?  Should be called Floating Piece of Shit.  This place should close up shop.  I wanted to grab a quick bite while I waited for my friend to meet up for some grub elsewhere.  I walk in and ask where the restroom was so I could wash my hands.  The lady immediately ASSumed that I wasn't going to eat there, and then directed me across the street.  

Once I told her that I was and just wanted to wash my hands, she pointed me in the right direction.  I get out and sit at the bar.  I'm watching these sushi rolls float around noticing the minute amount of fish inside, and the very thin slices of sashimi on top of the nigiri.  

I chose to just grab one of the rolls which was only 3 pieces.  It tasted like it had been made at 6am (with the rice getting hard on the outside) and was sitting there floating around for some sucker from out of town (ME).  Fortunately, my friend had called and said she was ready to go.  I tossed them down the hatch and paid my tab.

This is where I get the swift kick in the crotch!  $5.40 cents for 3 pieces of hardened shit.  I told the lady at the front but she didn't give a rats ass.  Nope.  Had not a care in the world of making things right.
author: Chris F.

description:
I went here because I was in chinatown and was really hungry and, was craving for sushi. This is not a place to eat sushi. For the first time in my life, I went to a restaurant here in san francisco, and was absolutely sure, that I will give them 1 star....

The fish was extremely bad, the tip of the tuna sashimi was hardened due to being left in the open for too long. The salmon was so gross, and whatever it is that they mix with their crabs, inside the californian roll, stinks. 

The waitress were nice, and I was able to eat 2 plates of sushi, a plate of jelly that taste, also really bad!! I'm, not a picky eater, and eat almost anything, this is almost not edible... I raised my hand in gesture for checks, upon realizing that I didn't eat 'enough' they all pretend not to see me. I have to try to get their attention for  a good 20 minutes, then they gave me the bill, and the smile was gone, as if, ' damn we want her to eat more!" too bad, the food is barely edible...
author: Kristin W.

description:
The first time I was there I had a ramen. the food was not bad and the price was okay. One problem: it was "fish cake ramen" without fishcake. After I requested the owner took out two tiny pieces of fish cakes without apologies. It came direct from the fridge and even tasted like the fridge. I won't say the owner is rude, but she is definitely very cold. Not even smiling back when I pay.

Anyway since my gym is really close the second time I stopped by there and I saw the "1 dollar sushi" sign. So I decided to give it another try. The actual price of the sushi was WAYYY over 1 dollar (I just saw other people commenting on this, I hated that I didn't see this earlier). In fact they are 3 dollar, 4 dollar and 5 dollar choices. So a few pieces of suchi cost me $15 bucks. It took me literally 5 minutes from sitting down to asking for the check, and I wasn't even full when I got out. The sushi was not delicious. Not fresh and much worse than Lee's deli dollar sushis. but the price is not your "budget dinner place in Chinatown" price. 

I noticed the first time I was one of the two customers there. And the second time I was by myself. I'm pretty curious how this place can keep running given it is relatively spacious (and clean! surprisingly). I hope the owner make some changes otherwise I'm sure it won't last very long. Realizing this I feel sorry for the owner. But it seems to be the only way out, as it apparently doesn't have any returning customers. At least I won't go there again.
author: Shirley W.

description: The sushi on the boats was so old that the rice on the top was dried out. For some reason my fiance kept on eating. Sushi roulette, perhaps? He is a daredevil. I ate a couple pieces and then the red alarms started going off. Our wise friend stopped at the nearest liquor store to buy a tiny bottle of whiskey. Flawless reasoning: Kill it with fire. He only got a little sick. My fiance, on the other hand, was out of commission for a good 24 hours. Five days later and he's still having issues. Avoid this place at all costs. It is not even good sushi and you will most likely end up in the bathroom for hours and breaking out in the sweats.
author: Erin M.

description: I have been to some of the best and worst sushi restaurants around California and this place is by far the worst that I have ever eaten at. My family and I thought it would be fun to eat here because of the gimmick with the floating boats at the sushi bar but even before we had sat down, the waitresses were already giving us attitude. We asked for water and it took 20 minutes before they came and asked us what we wanted to drink. The sushi that was going around on the boats had rice that looked old and mushy. My brother and I attempted to stomach the California rolls which didn't taste terrible. Within an hour of eating there, my entire family felt ill. My advice, if you enjoy diarrhea and shot-gunning Imodium, this is your place, otherwise AVOID AT ALL COSTS!
author: Daniel B.

description: Slow service is a understatement, overpriced crappy food. Party of 6 and they add $10 tip? Never again, waste of $80
author: Jonathan B.

description:
This place is a total ripoff.  Our bill was $77.  I could not understand the lady when she explained it to me, although I had no problem understanding the woman when she took our order.  I realize now, I probably tipped 15% and paid an 18% gratuity.  I am so angry, if I weren't back in Los Angeles writing this, I'd go back and give the woman a piece of my mind.

The watermelon juice was delicious.  The food was so-so.  At the ridiculously inflated prices, however, it all sucked.
author: Ted G.

description:
ZERO STARS

I love conveyor-belt sushi places -- all of the places I've been to are in Washington-- so this place came close so I was happy to see it.  I dragged my boyfriend and went in ready to tackle whatever sushi came my way. 

OMG. Their sushi SUCKS. It's all california roll with either shrimp or plain cali roll. She probably made a rainbow roll once.. I had to grab it before someone else got to it. The rest were something on a ball of rice. And it didn't look fresh. Their seaweed salad was loaded with sesame oil. Their hot tea was very diluted. I didn't each much, but I paid as much as i would at Jimisan -- should've gone there instead! 

You won't see me back there. ever.
author: Char D.

description:
They call this a sushi restaurant, but from the smell of the place when you first enter I'd have guessed they dealt exclusively in the cat food trade.

I love the fun sushi boat idea, but this place sucks, I'm sorry. The place was completely vacant when we went (RED FLAG) and the hostess was rude and seemed harried by the fact that we had come in at all.

I didn't dare sample any of the sushi that was making the rounds in the water canal, it looked old and had probably been 'round the center all day. Yuck. I ordered a Rock'n Roll instead, which although prepared fresh was far from it. Double yuck. That was enough for me.

On a cultural note, I'll point out the sheer lunacy of having a Japanese restaurant in the heart of Chinatown. That makes no g*ddamn sense, people. My guess? Some marketing 'guru' found this open space and thought "Hmm, tourists + no understanding of Asian cultures + tourist dollars = sushi place on Grant Avenue!" Awful.
author: Wes T.

description: Horrible establishment with rude servers, gross food, and dirty everything. I didn't expect the greatest service considering we were in Chinatown, but this place literally set the record for worst dining experience ever. We came in at around 2pm on a Sunday and were not greeted at all. The waitress directed us to sit at the bar and quickly and unwillingly explained to us how the system worked. I saw a bug crawling on the table but didn't even bother to point it out because of the waitress's attitude. The plates are differentiated by the design of the plate that corresponds to the pricing. All the dishes looked like they had been sitting out for a while and everything just looked very un-fresh. All the sushi is premade and stored in these disgusting boxes. Every once in a while, the waitress will transfer the sushi from the box to the plates on the boats. I was so disgusted that I only had one plate of eel nigiri. After we ate, we went up to the register to pay and ran into another problem. My plate was $4.40 so I handed her a $20 bill. The corner of my bill was slightly ripped and she said she couldn't accept it and even argued with me and asked if I would accept a ripped $20 bill if I were in her shoes. That was literally the tipping point for me. I didn't have any other cash on me so I was about to just walk out because I was so fed up. There is a $10 minimum on credit cards but she ended up making an exception and let me use my credit card. Never in my life would I ever come back!
author: Josephine C.

description:
I would rather have their cheap wasabi rubbed in my eyes before I would ever eat here. 

Let's start with the good......... Yeah, I've got nothin. 

I was not lured in here for anything more than somewhere for my wife & I to use the restroom. I actually was pleasantly surprised at the cozy decor & that lasted about 1.2 seconds when the annoyed waitress asked what we wanted. We ordered the tapioca teas so we were within the "customer bathroom only" category. 

We order our tea, take a seat, & each use the restroom. My wife was grossed out by the women's bathroom & I was repulsed by the men's. I think if I would've urinated all over the room I would've made the place cleaner! 

I accidentally walk into the kitchen when returning to our seat & see clean dishes and food sitting on the ground. Thank goodness we weren't eating there. 

I return to our seat to wait for our tea. It took a while considering they actually go down the street to another store to get it. 

As we are 15 minutes into us waiting another couple stops in to order a drink. About 5 minutes after that the lady returns from down the street with our drink & hands it the other couple. The assume it's theirs and walks out, it all happened so fast I didn't have time to stop it. 

So the lady who took our order starts yelling at the employee very loudly making all heads turn to them. So off she goes down the streets of china town to their undisclosed tea dealer.. 

She finally returns... Yes.... NO.......... She brought us the other couples order! Holy crap are u kidding me? I guess it's true what they say.. All white people look alike. Lol. 

Guess what happens next? Yup, off he goes to fetch the right drink. Now at this point I just wanted to get up leave. I Didn't even care about a refund. But I know that is just what this sushi geisha wanted, I wasn't caving in, I was going to wait for my shady tea!! 

It finally arrives. With nasty crap smeared all over the side. We walk out and a few minutes later we threw it away. I mean come in smeared brown stuff?!? I had enough of that from their bathrooms. 

So, pretty much we just paid to use their restroom. Which I am completely fine with. I would never eat here nor would I ever comeback for the bathroom.
author: Mikal W.

description: Service here was so so.  The sushi was good,  but nothing special. There are better options available.
author: Jeff N.

description:
Not too bad for a sushi train right in the middle of busy Grant Street Chinatown!  Was expecting a lot worse.

My husband and i stopped in on Saturday afternoon for a super late lunch.  We sat at the sushi bar and watched the little trays of sushi float around on boats.  We didn't order from the menu, but grabbed a few $1-3 trays and ordered some weak-but-hot tea.

So I'd say the sushi is average, but for a reasonably empty restaurant as soon as we sat down the lady started making more fresh rolls.  

The tuna was really fresh, though the tempura crab/veg rolls were revolting and cold - so stay away from them unless you see her make them fresh!  Hubby loved the pork dumpling and the seaweed salad was yummy.  The baclava honey-pastry slices are a little odd in a 'Japanese' restaurant, and were a little stale.  

Would say we might go again, but probably will try for a few better places nearby first before going out of our way to go there.
author: Beekay M.

description:
The food is great! I love the sushi bar. The dishes in the sushi bar are pretty cheap, but they charge by the plate, so it's easy to lose track of how much your spending if you're picking up plate after plate. It's still really delish though. 

The items in the menu are a bit more expensive, and last time I went, they took a bit of time to bring out the dishes, however, it was well worth the wait.
author: Reed C.

description:
What was the name of that sushi boat restaurant in Chinatown?  

You have to admit, the names of the stores here are practical.  If you can remember what it was, you are probably that close to remembering its name.  And really, with all the Chinese-owned and operated sushi bars in town, at least this one is totally above-board.  

The sushi is not as fresh as would be expected of a Japanese sushi restaurant, but remember where you are.  You're probably not here for the excellent cuisine, but rather to watch the boats float by in the canal.  And to visit the head, of course.  

The format is typical -- each serving is loaded on a color-coded tray, and paraded for your perusal.  The price you pay is completely under your control, although if you don't keep a watchful eye on your trays, you could feel plundered at the end of the day.  Our "snack" for three people -- yes, we saw it coming -- cost us about $45.  

Arrh, matey!
author: David D.

description:
Eh. We went during a Chinese New Year street fair so the turnover was good (read: fresher sushi) but still not great.

We mostly ordered off the menu, and stuck to the $2-3 plates instead of the $3-5.
Sushi was mediocre, prices were mediocre, service was bad.

We didn't get sick, but I wouldn't go back.
author: L B.

description:
I would give 0 if I could.  I really wish I consulted yelp first but was a random walk past, and the fact I hadn't seen a Sushi train (ok boat. train. same thing) at all so far lured us in.

We are japanese food freaks, and have started to eat through San Francisco's massive selection of cafe's/restaurant.
This was the 3rd place and i really REALLY hope this is an exception as it is the worst I have ever come across. EVER.
Sweet FA choices of sushi, what was there was old. 
I asked if they had Tako Yaki (common in Sushi cafe's) and I was just grumbled at..... I guess that means no?

So 2 crappy cheap plates each and a drink and we were out of there.... and yet was still $20.

Never again. Avoid like the plague.
author: Monica C.

description:
Avoid this place at all costs, and unbelievably it is costly. The waitress is obviously the spouse of the husband and wife team that run the place. It's costly, she's unfriendly to militant, and the food is mediocre. The boat gimmick is arcade-like and a real miss.
When in Chinatown, eat at the places that have names you cannot pronounce.
author: Drew S.

description: If there is a zero star that would be it. The waitress acts like you own her a mil bucks. Food is terrible, and expensive for an average place like this. Hope they shut down soon
author: Michelle T.

description:
Wondering around in the Chinatown, and drop in for lunch...
The food of your free choice, Sushi - Floating on the Boat, is pretty decent. Large Piece, quit Fresh..... 

Different plate comes with different price tag, free to browse and snag whatever any at your own will;  there for, never walk into a Sushi place when you can chow down a COW....  

The Three-Pieces-Made-Up Plate Size was truly fulfilling, for a quick-light lunch....but after just three plates and a glass of diet coke.......... it was ENOUGH for both stomach-fulfilling and money-spending.

This is not a fast food restaurant. 
Cause They REMIND me that the "generous" tip is "required".
Such request wasn't much of a turn off after a meal, but the attitude right behind the register has certainly cross the line.  

Though i receive with the minimum services.
author: Andrew W.

description: This place SUCKS!  1.awful service 2.added 10% tip on meal without knowledge for 4 people 3. quality of food blah!  We just got ripped off tonight at the place. The manager was rude.  The server didn't bring us chopsticks for our food, forgot half our order and we had to ask twice for miso soups and avocado rolls.  The yam roll was a fried potato roll.  I would never set foot in that place again. Rude and horrible service!
author: DaKine J.

description: These fucken idiot waitresses and staff were so rude!! They have no fricken manners or don't know the meaning to customer service. Kick rocks. Go to japan town
author: Alex S.

description: Admittedly, we were hungry and not thinking clearly.  This was definitely not a great first choice in a city so well known for great cuisine.  The sushi was okay but not outstanding by any means.  The little boats are cute but outside of that I am certain better value/taste could have been found had we walked a little further down the road.
author: Jessica F.

description: I am not surprised at the fact that I'm reading such a high number of negative reviews for this restaurant. I am not from SF, in fact I'm just visiting for a few days from LA. So as a tourist I came into this restaurant mostly because it looked like the most attractive little spot in Chinatown for a snack as I was walking down the street site seeing. That being said, I walked in and sat by the sushi bar where the little boats seemed to look super cute to me. I giggled at the site and went to grab my phone to take a picture. That's when the owner so rudely came over to ask me in the most rude possible way if I was going to take pictures or eat? Of course I just put my phone away, apologized for it and asked for a menu and water. I'm not a negative person so I just disregarded her rude tone. She on the other hand was obviously the opposite because she was such a negative person. She came back to my table with the menu and water I asked for and basically threw it beside me. I disregarded that as well, being that I felt obligated too since I accidentally offended her by trying to take pictures. I didn't trust the sushi so I just order vegetables, and edimami as a snack. She brought them both over but I saw two pieces of shrimp in my vegetable plate and figured they just fell in since I didn't order shrimp. I didn't eat them because again I didn't trust any fish lol. I get my check and it's a whopping $35 for water, edimami, and a small plate of veggies. Really? I asked why she charged a $7 gratuity and why the veggie plate was $18. She said because it had shrimp and because that's how waiters make the money! In my head I was like are you serious! But she must have read my body language and noticed how upset I was. Instead she decides to even more rudely say to just pay the check and go if I didn't like it. Ugh Ticked me off so bad but I paid my tab and left anyway. I don't need negative energy from a stranger. So people please beware of the awful service and energy this place provides.
author: Abigail A.

description:
This is place is well ......... in San Francisco Chinatown, you have that as a first clue it stinks, right? I went there with two friends, each of us received terribly crappy service, even though there wasn't much service but a freaking bagel dog pass me by, it's like he said with his last bit of voice, "Help me." 

 I really can't believe I got sucked into the tourist booby trap, the 99 cents sushi, the only thing that was 99 cents was brown spotted jello (don't think they have switched that out in a while) and a few cookies that were by the way VERY stale. I do believe they get all there drinks at a store few blocks down. Buddy, that's a little non-original. 

Oh yeah, did I tell you my waitress was the worst one in the W.O.W.(world of waiters)  I don't think anyone likes to work there, considering her trying to sneer or glare at me. 

All they really had were California rolls and a bagel dog, so sad. 

If you are looking for a good place to dine, cross this off your list, maybe actually, cross this off everyone's list
author: Shawn K.

description: Sure, the sushi isn't the best there is, but for a quick 99 cent snack, why the heck not? I have been visiting this cute spot since I was a young girl, and not much has changed. It is quiet and humble and inexpensive. It is on a corner and you can choose a seat at the floating boat bar, in a quiet corner, or next to a window where you can watch the hustle and bustle of adorable Chinatown. The staff was friendly and kept refilling my green tea.
author: Alexandra S.

description: Flies on the sushi boats...yuck! Saw the same pieces revolve the entire hour of dining; who knows how long they were there before we arrived. Rude servers...seated at the bar and five minutes later gave our drink order and food order after flagging down a waitress. Not a long wait for the food was a plus. The wait for the bill was ridiculously long...my boyfriend walked to the bakery down the street and back twice before we even saw our bill! We walked it up to the register to pay because it seemed the waitress didn't want our money. Not a place I recommend coming to if you're in a hurry and want fresh food!
author: Amy B.

description:
That was unequivocally the worse Japanese food I have ever had in this City and I have been t many of them that were bad but nothing has ever beat this. I have walked by this place many times on the way up to Chinatown but had not had a chance to go in and try it, I should have kept walking. I am super glad I did not get sick and had to run to Macy's or something.  I have been to other sushi boat places, like sushi bune on Geary and expected at least something Japanese floating instead of pork bun and other Chinese stuff. Should have been my first clue to head down the hill and go somewhere else. 

I had their combo of Tempura and sashimi along with suonomo. I wish I had went some where else and saved my money because really the food was not even passing (Meaning I could choke it down). The Sashimi part of my combo was frozen, when i bit into it there was bits of ice and I am not even sure what kind of sashimi it was. It was red and lacked any taste. That is a big no no in my book, you do not serve me frozen raw fish. Though I do have to admit that the Tempura was not too bad, no taste, but at least the batter was fried. The suonomo on the other hand had too much low quality cucumber and looked very sloppy. My motto is just because I finished the plate , does not mean I loved the food; well in this case i did not even finish the food. Just stay away! I eventually went to a real Japanese restaurant and downed some real good sake.
author: Christopher C.

description:
What a shame. After the absolute boredom of encountering too many conveyor belt sushi places these days, this restaurant has the best and cutest antidotes.

The food is carried round a little moat on little boats. A great novelty in presentation. Unfortunately the sushi is only average at best. If the quality of the food supported the innovative concept, this would be a real winner.

Hey, these isn't one of these back in London yet........
author: Yee Gan O.

description:
Just got back from this place with a couple coworkers of mine.  One of the girls ended up killing a few baby roaches in our very brief lunch visit.  Never going there again.

And they automatically charged us gratuity. (for a party of 3).
author: David H.

description:
Wow,
i've had better sushi from a road side super market in Denver, Colorado! I had the top-o-the-line super dupper roll and i am 90% sure they used canned fake crab and the spicy tuna was scraps from the floor. The only reason this place is still going is its location in the heart of china town which gives it a ton of tourists... which is sad because this is going to be a tourist impression of sushi in SF.
author: Lindonesia S.

description:
Doctor Seusshi ate here some years ago, according to some loose pages that fell out of his journal. He was supposed to try dim sum or won ton noodle soup, but somehow found himself on the touristy side of Grant Street and gave into raw fish temptation yet again.

The only comment he made according to the writeup was something along the lines of 

Meh

and

at least the integrity of my o-ring remains intact, phew!
author: Ken K.

description:
Was hiking from Union Square to Fisherman's Wharf via Chinatown and North Beach and stopped here for lunch.  We were greated as soon as we entered and had our orders taken promptly by a friendly female waiter.  

Has a delicious Donburi Beef and my partner had the House Sushi with salmon.  It definately was not haute cuisine but if you are advertising .99 cent sushi on your windows there is no pretension that you are either.  Definately got what I expected as I would not expect to get 5 star Japanese food in Chinatown not expect 5 star Chinese food in Japan town.

Worth a stop for a light lunch or a snack.  $25.10 for the 2 meals and one green tea before tip.
author: Lester R.

description:
Usually, I hate these places.  No, not because I don't like sushi; rather, I love sushi more than a morbidly obese child loves twice-fried Twinkies.  It's because I hold these raw fish creations with such esteem that I eschew any and all restaurants that serve it on tiny water vessels that have sailed the health-violation seas for hours on end.  

You know the places I mean.  Someone in the restaurant industry had the genius idea to cut back on waiters and instead serve raw fish on mini boats that circle the sushi bar until someone decides it looks appetizing.  No matter that the raw flesh often sits out all day, or that hordes of people breathe their hot, germ-y breath all over the sushi, or that many of the most indecisive patrons reach for one, pull it from the boat, examine it, and then put it back, only to repeat said health code violation until satisfied.  

However, this place felt a little different.  The fish was surprisingly fresh and lacked the film that often coats food that sits unnoticed while begging for attention.  The rolls were interesting and varied.  The presentation wasn't half-assed.

Though I wouldn't actively pursue going here again, if I were again meandering through Chinatown and needed somewhere fast, cheap and Japanese to dine, I would surely consider dining at Floating Sushi Boat again.
author: Christine M.

description:
I brought my 14yr niece here for her birthday. I did like the floating boats with all of their sushi. The service was low key, which is fine. As the boats are floating pass you are are to pick you dish and then they charge you by which plate you choose. 
The quality of the sushi was 'OK' I am not to sure if I would go back anytime soon.
author: Der Maibaum L.

description: Was on vacation with my family in San Francisco. My eldest son wanted to get some Sushi while in Chinatown. We saw the restaurant and it looked interesting - should of remembered the saying 'never judge a book by its cover'. It was an interesting restaurant but the service was poor and the quality and selection of the Sushi was terrible. I won't be visiting a restaurant in the future unless I check the reviews. As I read other reviews it would appear my visit was consistent. Avoid this restaurant.
author: Tom B.

description:
Seriously, just close down you damn losers. 

Waste of my time and money.

You draw me in with your $1 dollar sushi signs, then bait and switch. 

Me "$1 sushi really?" 

I sit down, and look for the $1 sushi. Everything that comes by cost more than that and the $1 ones are the nasty cucumber rolls or tamago(rice w/sweet egge) rolls.

The small sushi combination is nearly tasteless but cost about $15 + mandatory tip. 

Last time of visit, 4 1/2 years ago.
author: Keit K.

description:
It was good the first time I went. The people were nice and attentive to our needs. 
The second time was completely different. No one paid attention to my group. We literally had to go into the kitchen to get the check. It wasn't a pleasant experience.
author: Chelsea M.

description: Run for your life.  My God...the worst decision of my culinary life experiences.  It is a freaking boat...find a creek in your neighborhood and slap a goldfish on it...you would be better off.   Other than that, it was great.
author: G K.

description:
I was on my way back from yet another epic visit to doc andy's ( for kung fu and art and shit talking and back cracking and massage, and a nap to top it all off) 

and heading back to the Grant to ready myself for the OQO party @ the exploratorium later that night. My stomach was about to mutiny.

So in vain, i searched for premade dim sum. No dice. 7 pm on a friday and , well, chinatown is no clement st. So i stopped in @ floating sushi boat for a sad, sad snack, that i had wanted to be a meal.

The sushi chef was hanging out inside the table, but no sushi was made in the 40 minutes i spent there. I had the one remaining roll of salmon and tuna around mayonnaise with a garnish of rice and some avocado ( $ 4.95 for that plate !), a limp and greasy ( ?!?!??!?) seaweed salad from the parade of empty boats, and considered the eel every time it came around. Eel can be rubbery nasty, and when i realized that it was the same damn eel staring me in the face every 4 minutes, i understood that one bite of that, no matter how roasted and seasoned it was, and i would once again realize that i was chewing a snake. A rubbery, angry, nasty, snake.

No dice.

I paid $17 for NO service, No chef, and old sushi. I shouldn't have gone, i don't know what i was thinking. 

Please don't ever do something like that to yourself, you're out of their league... trust me.
author: Domini A.

description: Strange that nobody mentioned about automatic tip charge. Food was bad, service was horrible, and what makes it worse is that this place automatically add 18% tip to the bill. I asked why, and The reason is? They told me that because they are in the tourist business! Hello! My advice? Do not go there. Total waste of money.
author: Jin L.

description:
Lured us in...

...with the 99 Cent Sushi sign outside and the floating boats.
Warning, the only item that was .99 was jello on a boat.
All items including sushi, edamame, steak, katsu was mediocre at best.

We had a good time drinking sake bombs but for a party of 4 it cost us $150.
Kinda too steep for a store that have signs for .99 sushi outside.
author: Realtor Karl B.

description:
There are two keys to these kinds of places:

#1: Don't go to a floating sushi boat place in Chinatown.  Japantown, yes.  Chinatown, no.

#2: ONLY go to a floating sushi boat place when the place is packed.  If you don't have to wait to be seated YOU DON'T WANT TO BE THERE.  Why?  Because if you're the only one there, that sushi floating around on the boats has been there for a while.  But if the place is packed, they have to continually make fresh sushi to satisfy the throngs of people who, like me, can't get enough of fast food sushi.  

Ok.  Lesson over.  You can go back to wasting work time goofing off on the internet.
author: Jason S.

description:
I was four days new at my job.  The welcome lunches had subsided and for the first time I was on my own to venture out for food.  No one told me not to turn left on Grant. 

After wandering aimlessly for a good 10 minutes, I got desperate and ventured in here. I knew it would be bad, but I figured I'd just get a california roll to go to be safe. I mean it's one of those things you can't mess up that badly and I needed to get back to the office. Well, we know where this story is going.  

My california roll turned out to be a crunchy roll-- and not in the delicious bastardized american tempura way. They pulled this roll off the boat instead of making a new one and apparently this roll had sailed further than the Nina, the Pinta and Santa Maria combined because the rice had fossilized into a rock hard, impenetrably crunchy wall around the exterior of the roll. I couldnt even tell you how the inside of that roll was because I couldnt reach it. 

I'll admit, I actually look fondly at this place whenever I walk by because it's been a couple years and nostalgia has kicked in.  But like surviving any trauma, though it helped me build character, I wouldnt wish it upon anyone else.
author: Sha N.

description:
Beware!!! If  you want sushi, skip this place!!!

You know when you leave a restaurant with a bad taste in your mouth and feel like you've been cheated, that's exactly how i felt when leaving this place. One of the worse restaurant I've been to. Being a local i should have known better but we were too tired to look around and thought i would give it a try. The Sushi is the same quality as in Asian buffet. Very limited choice of sushi. They only had 5 different kind of sushi floating around. I had to order  a la carte. Bento box was meh. The service was awful. When i got the bill, they "sneaked" the tip in the bill even though we were 2 adults and a kid. I would understand if we were a large group but come on!!! 
Anyway, beware and check your bill when you go there. Don't expect much.
author: AE A.

description: Sushi is ok here. Rice is a bit too sticky tho the special roll portions are large. I liked the spider roll. The honey walnut roll not so much. The waitress was disinterested in me and about as cuddly as a porcupine. But she was efficient at least. Then again I shouldn't expect too much of a novelty sushi joint in Chinatown. It'll do in a pinch but if you like sushi and eat it a lot this place won't rank for you.
author: Andy W.

description: Don't walk in. It's that bad.... *shudder from the thought of eating here again*
author: Cliff T.

description:
For a quick meal, you could possibly do worse, but not easily.  I went sometime last year (only writing this today because I walked by and remembered how bad it was) and there was nothing good about the experience.

The hostess/waitress was rude, the sushi on the little boats was overpriced and not good, and the stuff we ordered prepared fresh was just as bad.

As has been pointed out by most other reviewers, this is clearly just a tourist trap restaurant.
author: Joseph N.

description:
We walked in off the street, not having yelped before hand. I wouldn't have gone in if I had seen the rating before hand. Not the worst in the world - the seafood was fresh at least! But it was nothing to write home about. Kind of expensive for this low-ish quality. 

The waitstaff ignored us for a long time, and looked like they did not want to be there. I am a waitress of many years, and I know it can be done better.
author: M A.

description: It was fine for a quick afternoon snack of a few rolls and some green tea becuase I couldn't wait to eat until my bf got out of work.  That said, it's only good for a snack probably. Most of the rolls were crab based and went from there.
author: Mark S.

description: I ran across review for this restaurant while looking for sushi restaurants on our next trip to S.F. This is by far, the worst restaurant I have ever been in to! Our salads had rotten black/green pieces of lettuce in them. The sushi was old; I don't know how long it had been floating around up there. When I bit into my tempura broccoli, it was brown and rotten inside. So gross. We told and showed them all of this. The looked at us with blank looks. We asked for our money back, but they still had us pay for our drinks! It's the first and only time I had the urge to run to every table and warn patrons to leave!
author: Kelly P.

description:
Who says you're not supposed to play with your food? Floating Sushi Boat, not to be confused with the Sushi Boat, is a cute convenient restuaraunt in Chinatown. 
What can I say, the sushi is OK, but it's a quick cheap place to pickup some lunch if you're in the area doing some shopping and/or dodging tourists at China Bazaar.
author: Jordan V.

description:
Tasteless sushi
Rude server
Gross smell (not sure if it was my server or the fish LOL)
Mediocrity
Won't be back
author: Sarah W.

description: Pleasantly surprised by the quality of the nigiri. Selection of rolls wasn't great but price per plate was on par with what I've come to expect from food served on miniature boats. At 8pm on a Friday after a long walk with some out of towners this can't be beat.
author: Jordan P.

description: We stopped into Floating Sushi Boat Restaurant for the novelty of it, and not expecting a great lunch.  The sushi were fine, but the selection of sushi on the boats was poor, limited to 4 or 5 choices.  The price did seem reasonable.  The space itself is blah, without much character, but it seems clean and tidy.  It was fun to go see the boats anyway.  lol
author: Jeremiah C.

description: At work and in the mood for sushi and our first choice being closed for the holiday week, we headed up the California hill to Chinatown to check out this place we had passed the other day.  You sit down and watch little boats float around and pick off sushi plates of varying prices and kinds.  The quality was ok, though I thought the tuna rolls looked a little suspect by how dark the tuna was.  I spent $22 for what I felt was an average amount and a draft Sapporo.  It was ok.  I think the quality was not bad, but for how much I got, the price was a bit much.  But it's fun to watch the boats float around and it's fast if you aren't in the mood for waiting.
author: Marc S.

description: I didn't get lured in by the .99 cents sign.  My girlfriend wanted to try it out even if we were the only ones there on a weekday.  I notice as I ride the bus it has more tourists inside on the weekends.  We had the teriyaki steak combo and rice.  Phily roll and California roll.  Another my girlfriend got from the boat to take home to eat.  The total was $40.00.  The was pretty good for my taste.
author: John F.

description:
We didn't intend to go here.

The idea was to go to get dim sum, but somehow we failed to find a place that was satisfactory to all of the party's members, and after about an hour of wandering the streets of Chinatown hung over and starving, we stopped to eat here.

That said, I'd venture to go so far as saying that this is one of the best places in the City to get overpriced mediocre sushi, especially if you're not into prompt service.

And, what's up with no free drink refills?? Cheap bastards.
author: Nick S.

description:
This is a tourist trap and unfortunately I fell for it.  Exploring Chinatown when I stumbled across this place.  "Floating sushi boat, cool!", I thought to myself.  No, self. Not cool.  Not cool at all.

Sushi was just stale.  The same boats went around over and over again.  I was left by my lonesome.  No service.  Finished what I could, told the waiter to take a picture of me and bounced.
author: Alex T.

description: I'll never go to this place again.  We happened to stop here b/c we were hungry.  The place isn't clean, the service sucks, and to top it off the sushi fish smelled fishy (if you know what I mean).  I had to stand up to find the waitress to ask her napkins, spoons, pay the bill.  Horrible!!!! Is there such a thing as no star rating?
author: Ethel-Lynn Q.

description:
I'm going to agree with most of the other reviewers here, its okay, but the food could either be a lot better or a lot cheaper.

Place is on the corner of Sacramento and Grant, been past here a bunch of times, and wondered what it would be like to eat 99c sushi. Decided to take a few mates and check it out. Obviously the 99c stuff is crap, and the better stuff is more expensive.

For instance $2.99, $3.99 and $4.99 for sushi, like inside out California or Philly rolls. The upside is the $6 large Asahi's - definitely makes it easier to enjoy the day.

Overall, there is nothing adventurous here, the boats that float on the moat are pretty cool, but you have to question how long its been sitting there. Place is never really packed, even for lunch on Grant St. But... per person it works out to about $25, which for average sushi sucks.
author: Joseph T.

description:
I ate here a couple of years ago on a whim.  I like kaiten style sushi, of which there is not enough of in SF.  But I don't like poor service, a poor selection, and most importantly, FLIES!

I'm often in Chinatown with my husband, and he has a bad memory and often suggests this place, and I always remind him of the unbelievable quantity of fruit flies infesting the sushi.  YUCK.
author: Lulu B.

description:
I don't think I've felt any worse walking out of a "restaurant" (if it even deserves that designation).

We were starving while walking through Chinatown and this place happened to be across the street when our hunger had reached a point where we didn't want to wait anymore.  We should have thought better and made our stomachs suffer a little longer while we searched for something else.

We were seated rather quickly, which was probably the only positive moment of our entire experience.

When the woman came to take our order, my friend placed his order for 2 sushi rolls, but before I could even begin to give her my order, she ran off unannounced to grab another piece of paper with which to write our order on.

The food took excessively long to get to our table.

I ordered the dinner combination (two entree items with salad, rice, and miso soup).  My entree items came to the table before the rice and salad, even before the miso (what even semi-legitimate Japanese restaurant does this?!).  None of this showed up till at least 45 minutes after we placed our order

My friend's bowl of rice came AFTER my dinner combo, and my friends two sushi rolls (two! TWO!!!) came 10 minutes after this!  All of this with nothing even remotely resembling an apology or other gesture.

The food?  Extremely lackluster at best.  My beef teriyaki came out room temperate, and my friend's sushi was far from tasty.  We never once had a waitress show up while we were eating to refill waters or ask how our food was.

When we were done with our food, I flagged down one of the waitresses and asked for our check.  She nodded OK and walked away.  15 minutes later, still no check.

Final straw?  We walked to the front counter expecting one of their to come serve us or otherwise we were planning on walking out.  Thankfully (for them and for us) one of their employees came and rang us up.  She also presented us with what confirmed that I will never visit this place again - a mandatory tip added to all checks.  We grudgingly paid our bills, and walked out with the newly found knowledge that we would never step foot in this establishment again.
author: Kellen H.

description:
My cousin and I just came back from a vacation there over this past weekend. We stopped by Chinatown our first day there because we had time since we couldn't check in early and our hotel was just a few blocks away. We passed by the restaurant and the floating boats caught our eyes, as I'm sure the same reason why alot of other people ate there. We later on decided to have dinner there that night. It wasn't planned, but we were hungry and didn't want to wait or search for any more restaurants after Alcatraz.

Do not be fooled by the look! The severs were unorganized and did not seem prepared. The one server did not have any answers to my questions and had to keep asking another server. The sushi chef behind the floating boat bar kept forgetting to make some of our rolls. And overall, when we arrived, and as more people arrived for dinner time, it took her forever to fill up the boats. Half of them were still empty by the time we left. The sushi did not even taste good at all. And it was kind of pricey and they did not look that fresh.

Do not waste your money and time!
author: Regina F.

description:
Worst Sushi Boat Experience Ever!
I usually like sushi boats for the same reason I usually like model train sets. It's cool. I mean, miniature vessels floating around, carrying delicious morsels of fresh raw goodness. What is there to not like?
Well, when the fresh raw goodness is not that fresh, your mood would be dampened immediately. That's what we found upon sitting down. The fish did not look fresh in those boats, and they actually put dim sum items in the boats as well. Now, to exacerbate the situation, these were items that were supposed to be served warm! On the boats, they are just cold pieces of leftovers.
The saving grace is that they are smart enough to serve fresh fish. This is done by giving you a menu for you to write in what you want. The chef prepares the sushi from behind the boats and hands you the dishes in a somewhat awkward angle.
author: Pete L.

description:
Pretty good sushi for a good price. I reccomend the crab sushi.. just delicious!!!!=) 
Very clean and the staff is suberb! I love the decorative boats floating around the bar..hence the name .....so cute!! 
Fills you up without breaking your bank..yaya!
B.T.W is is a nice place to relax if you want to get a way for a littl while from the crazy hustle and bustle of chinatown.


Two thumbs up!
author: Amy C.

description:
I wish I had read some reviews before I went here, but my smartphone was having a dull moment...

I went in because I'm a sucker now for the sushi boat concept, but this place was pretty lame.  In fact, business was so slow that the boats were just floating around empty and the waitress had to take our order.  Most disappointing of all, when the sushi came out it really just wasn't particularly special at all.
author: Irene C.

description:
The positives:  the sushi is cheap and the boba is good.  You get to eat very fast because you don't have to wait for your food, you just grab it off the little boats.

The negatives:  Not much variety, especially if you are a vegetarian.  Only avocado rolls as far as the sushi goes.  Even the meat eaters found not much variety in the selection.  And the few types of sushi we did get to try were not that great.  Also, even though you basically serve yourself, they still circled "tip" on our bill, making everyone feel far too guilty to leave without giving them one.  With so many good sushi places in the area, don't waste your time.  Just get some boba to go.
author: Rachael S.

description:
not worth your $. I had lunch on 10/28/2010. The ambiance was a little tired, but I was hungry and thought "great, quick sushi". Several of the nigiri I had were not fresh fish - they were gray around the sides. 
The selection was not great, many of the boats were empty, and the one lone (female) sushi chef looked like she was going to fall asleep behind the counter. I had to work to get her to notice me so I could order specific nirigi.

I ordered a side of edamame - it took 20 minutes to come, and for a small bowl which is about $2.25 at our normal sushi joints in Oakland, it was $4.50. 

Skip this place.
author: Jarrod K.

description: Sigh..............we should have gotten Dim Sum. We had my picky kid with us, and he eats sushi, but probably wouldn't have eaten much Dim Sum, AND this place was advertising sushi from 99 cents, so we gave it a try. The sushi was, of course, low quality, but you get what you pay for, so I wasn't surprised.............until I got the check, which came to 53 dollars for 3 adults and one kid. We didn't pig out or drink alcohol. Either give me cheap sushi or give me good sushi. This place wasn't either one.
author: Melanie I.

description: I love sushi.  However this sushi was definitely not up to par.  I was waiting for some friends to call so I decided to have a  snack.  As for most sushi boat places, you don't want the sushi on the boats especially if  the place is not busy.  This place was not busy.  The chef was sneezing constantly.  This place would have been below average for supermarket sushi and over-priced for the same.  The mackrel was passable and their veggie rolls were passible, but the fresh fish seemed a little sketch.
author: Richard H.

description: We ate here back in 2004, but it was a very memorable lunch. The sushi was very poor quality. The sushi chefs were very friendly and eager to fulfill requests. The wait staff, however, was rude and idle - gossiping with each other and ignoring their customers. I read that other reviewers had a forced gratuity added to their bill. That must be a new policy. The gratuity, actually, is what made this place so memorable. We had such a horrible time there I wasn't going to leave a tip. When the waitress saw that, she pushed the bill back in my face and demanded it. "THE TIP WASN'T INCLUDED."  There were only two of us and all we had was water, which was never refilled after the original serving.
author: Alexander Z.

description:
Wow.  My friends and I were volunteering at the Chinatown Street Fair one weekend.  Since we were getting a bit hungry, we took a quick stop by this place.  We sat down and they asked if we wanted tea.  Like any other place in Chinatown, we thought it'd be free.  So the four of us took our tea.  I, myself, didn't like tea, so I didn't drink much of it.  We looked at the sheet in front of us, displaying the prices of the plates.  They ranged from $0.95 to $4.95.  Every plate probably had about just 3 pieces of sushi.  The 1 dollars plates had the same rolls every time it took a trip around the bar.  Everything was cold, expensive, and tasteless.  Our bill was supposed to accumulate up to $31.  We ate just six plates, the four of us combined.  There, we waited for our bill.  We sat for about 20 minutes.  Two of my friends even waited in the long line for the restroom.  When we finally got the bill, it said $37.50.  They taxed the sushi, and they charged us for the tea.  We finally got the change back, which took another 10 minutes.  When we were staring at the money in utter shock, they took the time to take the change back, assuming it was their tip.

All in all, do NOT come here.
author: Karen L.

description: Rude staff that doesn't speek english and gets irritated when you do. The sushi was not fresh, and gratitude was included so you couldn't even protest by giving them low tip. Very expensive.
author: Amanda A.

description: was here a few years ago and this is where my sushi obsession began. the bar was set here and all other sushi is compared to the sushi I enjoyed here. A-M-A-Z-I-N-G. Melt in your mouth good and the freshest fare around.
author: Emily C.

description: Pretty horrible, came here with a couple of friends today, it was empty, the waiter there was horribly rude. We wanted to get a few things to go, and she just gave us the order, when we asked about some specials, she wasn't much help at all. The cost, way over priced for the amount of food given. Will definitely not recommend this place or every go back.
author: Matthew Y.
